critters.name: White-tailed Deer
critters.summary: Common woodland browser often seen near fields and feeders.
critters.fact: White-tailed deer use their fluffy tail as a warning signal to alert others of danger nearby.

critters.name: Black Bear
critters.summary: Largest forest mammal in Michigan woodlands.
critters.fact: Black bears have excellent memories and can remember food locations for years!

critters.name: Coyote
critters.summary: Adaptable predator common in rural areas.
critters.fact: Coyotes can adapt to diverse environments, thriving in cities as well as deserts and forests.

critters.name: Red Fox
critters.summary: Solitary hunter active in open woods and fields.
critters.fact: Red foxes have excellent hearing and can detect small animals digging underground, even beneath snow.

critters.name: Gray Fox
critters.summary: Smaller fox species able to climb trees.
critters.fact: Gray foxes are one of the few dogs that can climb trees to escape predators or hunt.

critters.name: Bobcat
critters.fact: Bobcats can jump up to 10 feet high, making them expert hunters and climbers in the wild!

critters.name: Porcupine
critters.fact: Porcupines have over 30,000 sharp quills for defense but cannot shoot them like arrows.

critters.name: Beaver
critters.fact: Beavers build dams using branches and mud to create ponds that protect their homes from predators.

critters.name: Muskrat
critters.summary: Small aquatic rodent near ponds and streams.
critters.fact: Muskrats build dome-shaped lodges using cattails, providing shelter and protection from predators in wetlands.

critters.name: Mink
critters.fact: Minks have waterproof fur that keeps them warm and dry while swimming in cold water.

critters.name: Fisher
critters.fact: Fishers are skilled climbers and can turn their ankles to climb down trees headfirst!

critters.name: River Otter
critters.summary: Playful aquatic predator found near rivers.
critters.fact: River otters can hold their breath underwater for up to 8 minutes while hunting fish!

critters.name: Eastern Gray Squirrel
critters.fact: Eastern Gray Squirrels use their bushy tails for balance and to communicate with other squirrels.

critters.name: American Red Squirrel
critters.fact: American Red Squirrels fiercely defend their territory, protecting food caches year-round to survive harsh winters.

critters.name: Chipmunk
critters.summary: Ground squirrel known for cheek pouches.
critters.fact: Chipmunks have cheek pouches to carry food back to their burrows for storing.

critters.name: Snowshoe Hare
critters.summary: Forest rabbit with seasonal coat change.
critters.fact: Snowshoe hares change fur color seasonally for camouflageâ€”brown in summer, white in snowy winter.

critters.name: Eastern Cottontail
critters.fact: Eastern Cottontails can run up to 18 miles per hour to escape predators!

critters.name: Raccoon
critters.fact: Raccoons have incredibly sensitive front paws, helping them identify food by touch even underwater!

critters.name: Opossum
critters.fact: Opossums are immune to snake venom and can survive bites from venomous snakes like rattlesnakes!

critters.name: Striped Skunk
critters.summary: Night forager known for defensive spray.
critters.fact: Striped skunks can spray a smelly liquid up to 10 feet to defend themselves from predators.

critters.name: Flying Squirrel
critters.fact: Flying squirrels glide using a special skin flap called a patagium between their legs.

critters.name: Little Brown Bat
critters.fact: Little Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects, navigating in total darkness with sonar sounds.

critters.name: Big Brown Bat
critters.fact: Big Brown Bats can live over 20 years, using echolocation to catch insects in complete darkness!

critters.name: Barred Owl
critters.summary: Woodland owl known for 'who cooks for you' call.
critters.fact: Barred Owls have hoots that sound like "Who cooks for you? Who cooks for you all?"

critters.name: Great Horned Owl
critters.fact: Great Horned Owls have powerful talons, capable of exerting 300 pounds of pressureâ€”strong enough to crush bones!

critters.name: Blue Jay
critters.summary: Bold feeder visitor with loud calls.
critters.fact: Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away other birds and protect their food!

critters.name: Northern Cardinal
critters.fact: Male Northern Cardinals are bright red, while females have warm brown feathers with red accents.

critters.name: Black-capped Chickadee
critters.fact: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food using spatial memory!

critters.name: Tufted Titmouse
critters.fact: Tufted Titmice chat with neighbors using soft calls to stay connected while foraging.

critters.name: White-breasted Nuthatch
critters.summary: Tree climber often moving headfirst down bark.
critters.fact: White-breasted Nuthatches can climb down trees headfirst, unlike most birds that only climb upwards.

critters.name: Downy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Downy Woodpeckers are the smallest woodpeckers in North America, often spotted tapping on trees for insects.

critters.name: Hairy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Hairy Woodpeckers have a long tongue that wraps around their skull to catch insects deep in wood!

critters.name: Pileated Woodpecker
critters.fact: Pileated Woodpeckers create large rectangular holes in trees to find insects and build nests.

critters.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
critters.fact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers use their strong beaks to drill into trees searching for insects and sap.

critters.name: Mourning Dove
critters.fact: Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 miles per hour, making them swift and agile birds!

critters.name: American Goldfinch
critters.fact: American Goldfinches are unique among songbirds for molting twice a year, changing their bright yellow plumage.

critters.name: Dark-eyed Junco
critters.fact: Dark-eyed Juncos are often called "snowbirds" because they appear mostly in winter across North America.

critters.name: House Finch
critters.fact: House Finches are known for their bright red heads, which come from pigments in their diet!

critters.name: Purple Finch
critters.fact: Purple Finches sing sweet, melodic songs that help them attract mates and defend their territory.

critters.name: Wild Turkey
critters.summary: Large ground bird common in Michigan.
critters.fact: Wild turkeys can run up to 20 miles per hour to escape predators!

critters.name: Ruffed Grouse
critters.summary: Forest bird known for drumming display.
critters.fact: Ruffed Grouse create a unique drumming sound by rapidly beating their neck feathers to attract mates!

critters.name: Sandhill Crane
critters.summary: Tall wetland bird with loud call.
critters.fact: Sandhill Cranes perform elaborate dances to communicate and strengthen pair bonds during mating season.

critters.name: American Crow
critters.fact: American Crows use tools and can recognize human faces for yearsâ€”smart birds!

critters.name: Common Raven
critters.fact: Common Ravens can mimic sounds, including human speech, showcasing impressive intelligence and adaptability.

critters.name: Red-tailed Hawk
critters.fact: Red-tailed Hawks have incredible eyesight, spotting prey from over a mile away while soaring high!

critters.name: Cooperâ€™s Hawk
critters.fact: Cooperâ€™s Hawks are skilled flyers, able to weave through trees to catch their prey mid-air!

critters.name: Mallard Duck
critters.fact: Mallard ducks are famous for their iridescent green heads and are one of the most common wild ducks worldwide!

critters.name: Wood Duck
critters.summary: Colorful duck nesting in tree cavities.
critters.fact: Wood Ducks are excellent climbers, using their sharp claws to nest in tree cavities above water.

critters.name: Canada Goose
critters.fact: Canada Geese can fly thousands of miles during migration, forming a distinctive V-shaped flight pattern.

critters.name: Great Blue Heron
critters.fact: Great Blue Herons can stand still for minutes, patiently waiting to catch fish with their sharp beaks!

critters.name: Painted Turtle
critters.fact: Painted turtles can live over 50 years and are known for their brightly colored red and yellow markings.

critters.name: Snapping Turtle
critters.fact: Snapping turtles can bite with a force over 400 pounds per square inchâ€”strong enough to crush bone!

critters.name: Bluegill
critters.fact: Bluegill are colorful sunfish that use their flat bodies to hide in underwater vegetation.

critters.name: Largemouth Bass
critters.fact: Largemouth bass can grow up to 29 inches long and are popular game fish in freshwater lakes.

critters.name: Yellow Perch
critters.fact: Yellow Perch have bright yellow bodies with dark vertical stripes, making them easy to identify underwater!

critters.name: Northern Pike
critters.fact: Northern Pike have sharp teeth and can grow up to 4.5 feet long in the wild!

critters.name: Spring Peeper
critters.summary: Tiny frog with loud spring calls.
critters.fact: Spring peepers are tiny frogs known for their loud, high-pitched calls that signal early springâ€™s arrival!

critters.name: American Bullfrog
critters.fact: American Bullfrogs can grow over 8 inches long, making them one of the largest frogs in North America!

critters.name: Green Frog
critters.fact: Green frogs can jump over 20 times their body length to escape predators quickly!

critters.name: Leopard Frog
critters.fact: Leopard frogs get their name from their distinctive dark spots, which help them blend into grassy habitats.

critters.name: Garter Snake
critters.fact: Garter snakes can swim and often live near water, hunting frogs and small fish.

critters.name: Water Snake
critters.fact: Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to 30 minutes while hunting or hiding.

critters.name: Eastern Milk Snake
critters.fact: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic rattlesnakes by shaking their tails to scare predators without biting.

critters.name: Monarch Butterfly
critters.fact: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles from North America to central Mexico every fall!

critters.name: Swallowtail Butterfly
critters.fact: Swallowtail butterflies have tail-like wing extensions that help distract predators and protect their bodies.

critters.name: Dragonfly
critters.fact: Dragonflies can fly in six directions, including backward, thanks to their two sets of wings!

critters.name: Damselfly
critters.fact: Damselflies fold their wings along their body when resting, unlike dragonflies that keep wings open.

critters.name: Firefly
critters.fact: Fireflies use bioluminescence to attract mates, producing light without heat through a chemical reaction called "chemiluminescence."

critters.name: Honeybee
critters.fact: Honeybees communicate by dancing to share the location of tasty flowers with their hive mates!

critters.name: Bumblebee
critters.fact: Bumblebees buzz to communicate and help their colony find the best flowers for pollen and nectar.

critters.name: Grasshopper
critters.fact: Grasshoppers hear with tiny ears located on their bellies, not their heads!
